explanation:
For correctly assessing whether OS_CondVarUnlock or any of its reachable code violates the MISRA for-loop well-formedness rule you must examine all called code and the types/macros that affect control flow and return behavior. Each symbol is required for the following reasons:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee. Its implementation may contain for loops (or call other functions that do) whose loop counters or side-effects would contribute to rule violations when invoked from OS_CondVarUnlock.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Required to inspect any for loops or modifications to loop counters/objects used in loops in the transaction init path.
- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. May implement loops (index computations) that must be checked against the three-clause constraints and mutation rules.
- OS_ObjectIdConvertToken: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Could contain loops or modify objects used as loop counters; needed to determine transitive violations.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Transaction rollback code can contain loops; include to ensure no hidden violations.
- OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl: Direct callee. Its body is part of the target function's behaviour — any for loops here (or in its callees) must be checked for adherence to the rule.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Callee of OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl. Inspect for loops or counter modifications that would be considered part of the for-loop body when called.
- OS_object_token_t: The token type passed between functions; needed to understand whether loop control expressions reference members of this object (which would affect whether a loop uses objects modified in the body).
- osal_id_t: The ID type used as input; needed to see if any loops index or modify this object, or if conversions create loops.
- int32: The return type used for return_code; used to evaluate expressions in loop clauses if these variables are used as counters or flags.
- OS_SUCCESS: Return code sentinel used in the conditional after OS_ObjectIdGetById; required to understand control-flow decisions that may guard loops.
- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE: Argument passed into OS_ObjectIdGetById; include to check any macro-expanded behavior or conditionals that affect which code paths (and loops) execute.
- OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR: Object-type macro passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById; affects which code paths inside that function are executed (and hence which loops need checking).
- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These unit-test/stub framework symbols appear in the static call graph for OS_CondVarUnlock (or its callees). If any production function is replaced by stubs in the build under analysis, the stub implementations may themselves contain loops or alter control flow; include them so that any loop-related behaviour introduced by test stubs is also examined.

In short: to determine MISRA conformance for for-loops you must examine the bodies of all direct and transitive callees (listed above) and the types/macros that affect loop/control expressions. The symbols above are the minimal set needed to locate and review every function and object whose behaviour could be considered part of the target function's for-loop semantics.
